content.title: Adrenal Insufficiency
content.summary: Inadequate production of adrenal cortex hormones (cortisol ± aldosterone) causing fatigue, hypotension, electrolyte abnormalities, and potential life-threatening adrenal crisis
key_points: Primary AI (Addison's): Adrenal gland destruction; low cortisol, high ACTH, ± low aldosterone
Secondary AI: Pituitary ACTH deficiency; low cortisol, low/normal ACTH, aldosterone preserved
Tertiary AI: Most common; hypothalamic suppression from chronic glucocorticoid use
Autoimmune adrenalitis is most common cause of primary AI in developed countries
Morning cortisol <3 μg/dL diagnostic; 3-18 μg/dL requires ACTH stimulation test
Treatment: Hydrocortisone 15-25 mg/day in divided doses; fludrocortisone if primary
Stress dosing essential during illness, surgery, or trauma (double or triple dose)
content.statement: Adrenal insufficiency is a potentially life-threatening condition caused by inadequate production of glucocorticoids (cortisol) with or without mineralocorticoids (aldosterone), requiring lifelong hormone replacement and stress dose adjustments.

explanation.intuition: The adrenal glands are your body's stress response system. Without adequate cortisol, the body cannot mount appropriate responses to stress - blood pressure drops, blood sugar falls, and even minor illnesses can become life-threatening.
explanation.key_insight: The key to understanding adrenal insufficiency is the axis level: Primary AI destroys the adrenal gland itself (losing both cortisol AND aldosterone), while secondary/tertiary AI affects ACTH production (preserving aldosterone since it's regulated by renin-angiotensin). This distinction guides treatment.
explanation.technical_details: Primary AI causes elevated ACTH (loss of negative feedback) with elevated MSH causing hyperpigmentation. The cosyntropin (ACTH) stimulation test assesses adrenal reserve: cortisol should rise to >18-20 μg/dL at 30-60 minutes. Failure to respond indicates primary AI or longstanding secondary AI with adrenal atrophy.

definitions_glossary.primary_adrenal_insufficiency: Addison's disease; destruction of adrenal cortex causing cortisol and aldosterone deficiency
definitions_glossary.secondary_adrenal_insufficiency: Pituitary ACTH deficiency causing cortisol deficiency with preserved aldosterone
definitions_glossary.tertiary_adrenal_insufficiency: Hypothalamic CRH deficiency, typically from chronic exogenous glucocorticoid suppression
definitions_glossary.cortisol: Primary glucocorticoid essential for stress response, glucose metabolism, and immune modulation
definitions_glossary.aldosterone: Primary mineralocorticoid regulating sodium retention and potassium excretion
definitions_glossary.acth: Adrenocorticotropic hormone from pituitary stimulating cortisol secretion
definitions_glossary.cosyntropin_stimulation_test: High-dose ACTH (250 μg) test assessing adrenal cortisol reserve
definitions_glossary.hyperpigmentation: Skin darkening from elevated ACTH/MSH; occurs only in primary AI
definitions_glossary.adrenal_crisis: Life-threatening acute adrenal insufficiency with hypotension, shock, and electrolyte abnormalities
definitions_glossary.stress_dosing: Increased glucocorticoid doses during illness, surgery, or physiologic stress
definitions_glossary.fludrocortisone: Synthetic mineralocorticoid for aldosterone replacement in primary AI

pathophysiology.mechanism: Inadequate adrenal cortex hormone production due to gland destruction, pituitary dysfunction, or hypothalamic suppression

tertiary_ai: Chronic glucocorticoid therapy (most common cause overall)

distinguishing_features.primary_ai: Elevated ACTH, hyperpigmentation, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, aldosterone deficiency
distinguishing_features.secondary_tertiary: Low/normal ACTH, no hyperpigmentation, no hyperkalemia, aldosterone preserved

clinical_presentation: Hyperpigmentation (primary AI only) - skin creases, gums, scars

laboratory_criteria.screening: 8 AM cortisol: <3 μg/dL diagnostic; 3-18 μg/dL needs further testing; >18 μg/dL excludes AI
laboratory_criteria.acth_stimulation_test: 250 μg cosyntropin IV; cortisol <18-20 μg/dL at 30-60 min = positive
laboratory_criteria.additional_testing: 21-hydroxylase antibodies for autoimmune etiology; CT/MRI for structural causes

diagnostic_criteria.adrenal_crisis_features: Severe hypotension/shock, acute abdominal pain, fever, altered mental status, severe hyponatremia/hyperkalemia

glucocorticoid_replacement.hydrocortisone: 15-25 mg/day in 2-3 divided doses (e.g., 10 mg AM, 5 mg afternoon, 5 mg evening)
glucocorticoid_replacement.prednisone_alternative: 3-5 mg daily if once-daily dosing preferred
glucocorticoid_replacement.monitoring: Clinical symptoms, body weight, serum sodium (no reliable lab marker for dosing)

mineralocorticoid_replacement.monitoring: Blood pressure, serum potassium, plasma renin activity

stress_dosing.minor_illness: Double or triple maintenance dose for 2-3 days
stress_dosing.major_surgery_trauma: 100-150 mg hydrocortisone daily, tapered over 1-3 days
stress_dosing.adrenal_crisis: 100 mg hydrocortisone IV bolus, then 50 mg IV q6h or 200 mg/24h infusion

patient_education: Know when and how to stress dose
Seek medical attention for vomiting (can't absorb oral medication)

skos.definition: A condition of inadequate adrenal cortex hormone production causing fatigue, hypotension, electrolyte abnormalities, and potential life-threatening crisis requiring lifelong replacement therapy

learning_objectives: Differentiate primary from secondary/tertiary adrenal insufficiency
Interpret cortisol levels and ACTH stimulation test results
Identify clinical features distinguishing primary from secondary AI
Design appropriate glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement regimens
Apply stress dosing protocols for illness and surgery
Recognize and emergently treat adrenal crisis
clinical_pearls: Hyperpigmentation ONLY occurs in primary AI (elevated ACTH/MSH)
Hyperkalemia ONLY occurs in primary AI (aldosterone deficiency)
Most common cause of AI overall is chronic glucocorticoid use (tertiary)
Never stop chronic steroids abruptly - taper to allow HPA axis recovery
8 AM cortisol <3 μg/dL is diagnostic; >18 μg/dL rules out AI
Fludrocortisone only needed in primary AI (aldosterone preserved in secondary/tertiary)
Patients should carry emergency injection kit and wear medical alert identification
Dexamethasone doesn't cross-react with cortisol assay - use for empiric treatment pending diagnosis

step1_concepts: ACTH and MSH co-secretion from POMC
Aldosterone vs cortisol regulation (renin-angiotensin vs ACTH)
step3_concepts: Transition from IV to oral replacement
common_questions: Fatigued patient with hyperpigmentation, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia - diagnosis?
When is fludrocortisone needed in adrenal insufficiency?
